edge: Dragonball Evolution is a 2009 American superhero film directed by James Wong, produced by Stephen Chow, and written by Ben Ramsey.
Dragonball Evolution is loosely based on the Japanese Dragon Ball manga series created by Akira Toriyama.
Dragonball Evolution is directed by James Wong.
Dragonball Evolution is produced by Stephen Chow.
Dragonball Evolution is written by Ben Ramsey.
In the film, the teenager Goku reveals his past
Goku sets out to fight the evil alien warlord Lord Piccolo who wishes to gain the powerful Dragon Balls and use them to take over Earth.
Lord Piccolo wishes to gain the powerful Dragon Balls
Emmy Rossum, James Marsters, Jamie Chung, Chow Yun-fat, Joon Park, and Eriko Tamura star in Dragonball Evolution.
Dragonball Evolution grossed only $9.4 million in North America
and a worldwide total of $56.5 million against a budget of $30 million

node_2: trap set by desert bandit yamcha
edge: desert bandit Yamcha sets a trap to prevent Goku and Bulma from finding Roshi
Roshi convinces desert bandit Yamcha to join them by promising some of the royalties for Bulma's invention
Mai and her henchmen launch an ambush against Goku, Bulma, and Roshi to prevent them from finding Dragonballs
Goku's crush Chi-Chi
Chi-Chi is competing at The World Martial Arts Tournament.
Mai steals a sample of Chi-Chi's blood and assumes her appearance.
Goku accidentally knocks out Chi-Chi due to mistaken identity with Mai.
Mai steals the team's Dragonballs.
Chi-Chi helps Goku in his training to learn the most powerful of the ki-bending techniques: the Kamehameha Wave.
Roshi consults his former teacher Sifu Norris at a temple.
Roshi begins preparing a new Mafuba enchantment to reseal Piccolo.
In order to summon Shenron, all seven Dragonballs are needed.
During the battle between Piccolo and Goku's team, Piccolo reveals to Goku that he is his minion.
Piccolo reveals to Goku that he is Ōzaru the Great Ape, having been sent to Earth as an infant to destroy it.
The solar eclipse transforms Goku into Ōzaru.
Roshi attempts to use the Mafuba on Piccolo, but he doesn't have enough energy allowing Piccolo to break free.
In a final battle, Goku seemingly defeats Piccolo with the Kamehameha Wave.
Before heading out, Goku meets with Chi-Chi and apologizes for knocking her unconscious.
As the group celebrates, Bulma declares that the Dragonballs have scattered, and that they must search for them again. Chi-Chi wakes up and starts a sparring match with Goku.
In a mid-credits scene, Piccolo is revealed to be alive and treated by a mysterious woman.

In 1995, Hong Kong action film star Jackie Chan expressed interest in adapting Dragon Ball into a live-action film, but noted that it would require 'a lot of amazing special effects and an enormous budget.' This illustrates the potential for Dragon Ball to be transformed into a different medium, specifically a live-action film.

Dragon Ball creator Akira Toriyama stated in 2013 that 'nobody came to mind' for the role of Goku, but if it were back when Jackie Chan was still young, he supposed 'I would have thought nobody could play Goku but him.'

node_2: shueisha, publisher of toriyama's original manga series
edge: In 2002, 20th Century Fox acquired the live-action feature film rights to the Dragon Ball franchise from Shueisha, publisher of Toriyama's original manga series.

In 2002, 20th Century Fox acquired the live-action feature film rights to the Dragon Ball franchise from Shueisha, publisher of Toriyama's original manga series. Mark Schilling reported that Toriyama was engaged by 20th Century Fox as a creative consultant.

In 2007, James Wong and RatPac-Dune Entertainment co-founder Brett Ratner were announced as director and producer respectively, and the project was retitled Dragonball. Ben Ramsey's first draft was deemed too expensive to shoot.

Stephen Chow, publisher of Toriyama's original manga series, explained he would only serve as a producer because he believes that he should only direct stories he had created.

Certain visual elements in the film were created here.

The film's soundtrack, Dragonball Evolution: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack, was released on March 17, 2009.
The score for Dragonball Evolution was composed by Brian Tyler.
Brian Tyler recorded the score for Dragonball Evolution with an 82-piece ensemble of the Hollywood Studio Symphony at the Newman Scoring Stage at 20th Century Fox.
It was confirmed on December 9, 2008, that the theme song for Dragonball Evolution would be 'Rule' by Japanese singer Ayumi Hamasaki.
American pop artist Brian Anthony, whose remixed song 'Worked Up' was featured on the film's soundtrack, was released as a single in English territories.
A film novelization for Dragonball Evolution, entitled Dragonball Evolution: The Junior Novel, was written by Stacia Deutsch.
Stacia Deutsch wrote Dragonball Evolution: The Junior Novel in collaboration with Rhody Cohon.
A series of chapter books for readers aged 7–10, entitled The Discovery, were written by Deutsch.
Another volume in the series, titled The Search, was also written by Deutsch and Cohan.
The third and final volume of the chapter book series for readers aged 7–10, entitled The Battle, was also written by Deutsch.
A week after the release of Dragonball: Evolution Posterzine on March 31, 2009, was published by Viz Media.
A 16-paged sticker book for Dragonball: Evolution, entitled Dragonball: Evolution Sticker Book, was also released by Viz Media.
Dragonball: Evolution, an American film, was released in Japan on March 13, 2009, nearly a month before its American release.
Dragonball: Evolution, an American film, was also released in Hong Kong on March 13, 2009, nearly a month before its American release.
In time for the theatrical release of Dragonball: Evolution, Bandai America released a mass-market toy-line based on the movie.

A 1:6-scaled line for Dragonball Evolution was produced by Enterbay. Figures of Goku and Lord Piccolo were released, and Bulma was planned as the third figure in addition to being the first female figure Enterbay has ever released.
Japanese toy company MediCom created stylized Goku and Piccolo Be@rbrick toys to coincide with the release of Dragonball: Evolution.
The July 2008 issue of Jump Square published a manga by Daisuke Kadokuni, inspired by the film.

The film's marketing campaign included a viral 'personal expressions' campaign and the release of a PC/Wii flash game titled Can you Ka-Me-Ha-Me-Ha?, encouraging fans to send in their renditions of the fighting move.

The release date of the film was changed multiple times, initially scheduled for August 15, 2008, then moved to April 2009 for additional filming and post-production work, and finally released on April 10.
The marketing of the theatrical release included a viral 'personal expressions' campaign created by digital agency Red Box New Media.

Initially annoyed at fans of the franchise who criticized the film via leaked set shots and trailers before the film's release, eventually gave the movie a negative rating and capitulated that 'the fans were right.'

In a 2013 interview with Asahi Shimbun, Toriyama revealed that he had felt the script of Dragonball Evolution did not 'capture the world or the characteristics' of his series and was 'bland' and not interesting, so he cautioned and gave suggestions for changes. But the Hollywood producers did not heed his advice, 'And just as I thought, the result was a movie I cannot call Dragon Ball.'
At the 2014 Wizard World Convention, actor James Marsters expressed feelings that he was misled about Dragonball: Evolution, claiming, "they told me it was a $120 million picture,"...
...claiming, "and that Stephen Chow was producing. And I get out to Durango, Mexico and it's a $30 million picture,"...
...claiming, "and Stephen Chow is just on paper to fool us down into the desert,"...
At the 2014 Wizard World Convention, actor James Marsters expressed feelings that he was misled about Dragonball: Evolution, claiming, "they told me it was a $120 million picture,"...
...claiming, "and it's a $30 million picture and Stephen Chow is just on paper to fool us down into the desert. And they don't even want to pay for the stuntman to get made up like me,"...

Writer Ben Ramsey apologized for the "following his work on the film, writing: "To have something with my name on it as the writer be so globally reviled is gut-wrenching. To receive hate mail from all over the world is heartbreaking,"...

"...following his work on the film, was chasing after a big payday, not as a fan of the franchise but as a businessman taking on an assignment. I have learned that when you go into a creative endeavor without passion you come out with sub-optimal results,"...
Following Akira Toriyama's death on March 1, 2024, Justin Chatwin took to social media to send his condolences
JoBlo.com nominated the film for its Golden Schmoes Awards in the category Worst Movie of the Year 2009.
Plans were in place for a sequel film at the time of release, indicating a direct relationship between the two concepts.
Marsters played King Piccolo in Dragonball Evolution and expressed interest in making up to seven films, suggesting a strong association between the two characters.
Marsters indicated his intention to fulfill the arc of Piccolo in live-action across all planned films, implying a connection between the actor and future movies.
Justin Chatwin stated that subsequent films would feature elements from Dragon Ball Z, hinting at a potential tie between the series and future movies.
Chatwin suggested that Gohan's inclusion in future films was exciting due to his Saiyan origins, indicating a link between the character and subsequent movies.
Chatwin also expressed interest in including Vegeta in future films, suggesting an association between the character and planned movies.
Marsters' suggested arc for Piccolo could potentially merge his character with that of Piccolo Jr. In future movies, implying a connection between the two characters and planned films.
Chatwin and Chung expressed their hopes for Krillin's inclusion in future movies, suggesting a potential tie between the character and planned films.
The cancellation of planned sequels can be attributed to the poor box office and critical reception of Dragonball Evolution, illustrating a relationship between the two concepts.
